The Registrar may, at the request of any owner of a registered trade mark which contains or consists of the name or address of the owner or any previous owner, allow the alteration of that name or address but only to the extent that the alteration does not substantially affect the identity of the trade mark. (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 36)

subsection.leadIn: Provision may be made by the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as to the effect of any such alteration;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the publication in the official journal of particulars of any such alteration; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the making of objections by any person claiming to be affected by it.

subsection.content: The registration of a trade mark may be surrendered by the owner in respect of some or all of the goods or services for which the trade mark is registered.

subsection.leadIn: Provision may be made by the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as to the manner and effect of a surrender; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for protecting the interests of other persons having a right in the trade mark.

part.crossHeading: Rectification, correction and amendment of the register

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), any person having a sufficient interest may apply for the rectification of an error or omission in the register.
An application for rectification may not be made in respect of a matter affecting the validity of the registration of a trade mark.
An application for rectification may be made either to the Registrar or to the court.
Except where the Registrar or the court directs otherwise, the effect of rectification of the register is that the error or omission in question is deemed never to have been made.

The Registrar may, on request made by the owner of a registered trade mark or a licensee, or by any person having an interest in or charge on a registered trade mark the particulars of which have been entered in the register under section 29 (registration of transactions affecting registered trade mark), enter any change in his name or address, or in any other particulars identifying such person, as recorded in the register.
The Registrar may correct an error or omission in the register if satisfied that the error or omission is attributable to the Registrar. (Replaced 3 of 2020 s. 11)

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.leadIn: The power to correct may be exercised—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the Registrar’s own initiative; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on application in writing by a person having a sufficient interest. (Added 3 of 2020 s. 11)

subsection.name: 6B
subsection.content: Before making a correction, the Registrar must give notice of the proposed correction to any person the Registrar considers should be notified of the proposed correction. (Added 3 of 2020 s. 11)

subsection.name: 6C
subsection.content: To avoid doubt, the power to correct is exercisable regardless of whether the error or omission may affect the validity of the registration of a trade mark. (Added 3 of 2020 s. 11)
The Registrar may remove from the register matter appearing to him to have ceased to have effect.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Amendment of entries to accord with new classification, etc.

subsection.content: Provision may be made by the rules to empower the Registrar to do such things as he considers necessary to implement any amended or substituted classification of goods or services for the purposes of the registration of trade marks.
Provision may in particular be made by the rules to empower the Registrar to amend entries in the register so as to accord with the amended or substituted classification of goods or services.

subsection.leadIn: Where the rules empower the Registrar to amend entries in the register, provision shall also be made by the rules for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the giving of notice to any owner of a registered trade mark who may be affected by an amendment proposed to be made by the Registrar;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the publication in the official journal of particulars of the amendments proposed to be made by the Registrar;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the making of objections, within such time as may be prescribed, by any owner of a registered trade mark claiming to be affected; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the filing of oppositions, within such time as may be prescribed, by any other person claiming to be affected.

subsection.leadIn: Provision may also be made by the rules to empower the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to require the owner of a registered trade mark, within such time as may be prescribed, to file a proposal for amendment of entries in the register so as to accord with any amended or substituted classification of goods or services; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to cancel or refuse to renew the registration of the trade mark in the event of the owner failing to do so.

subsection.content: Any such power of amendment shall not be exercised so as to extend the rights conferred by the registration, except where it appears to the Registrar that compliance with this requirement would involve undue complexity and that any extension would not be substantial and would not adversely affect the rights of any person.

part.crossHeading: Acquiescence in use of registered trade mark

subsection.leadIn: Where the owner of an earlier trade mark or other earlier right has acquiesced for a continuous period of 5 years in the use of a registered trade mark in Hong Kong, being aware of that use, there shall cease to be any entitlement on the basis of that earlier trade mark or other earlier right—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: to oppose the use of the later trade mark in relation to the goods or services in relation to which it has been so used,

subsection.continued: unless the application for registration of the later trade mark was made in bad faith.

subsection.content: Where subsection (1) applies, the owner of the later trade mark is not entitled to oppose the use of the earlier trade mark or the exploitation of the earlier right, as the case may be, notwithstanding that the earlier trade mark or earlier right may no longer be invoked against his later trade mark.

part.name: P8
part.heading: Defensive Trade Marks, Collective Marks and Certification Marks

subsection.content: If a registered trade mark has been used so much in relation to all or any of the goods or services for which it is registered that it has become exceptionally well known in Hong Kong and, as a result, its use in relation to other goods or services would be likely to detract from its distinctive character in relation to the goods or services for which it has been so used, the trade mark may, on the application of the owner of the registered trade mark made to the Registrar, be registered as a defensive trade mark in respect of any or all of those other goods or services.

A trade mark may be registered as a defensive trade mark in respect of particular goods or services even if the owner of the registered trade mark does not use or intend to use the trade mark in relation to those goods or services.

A trade mark may be registered as a defensive trade mark in respect of particular goods or services even if it is already registered (otherwise than as a defensive trade mark) in the name of the applicant in respect of those goods or services.

A trade mark that is registered as a defensive trade mark in respect of particular goods or services may be subsequently registered (otherwise than as a defensive trade mark) in the name of the owner of the registered trade mark in respect of the same goods or services.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar shall refuse an application made under subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the trade mark is not registered as a trade mark in the name of the applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the extent to which the registered trade mark is being or has been used does not accord with the circumstances described in subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: Any person may apply to the Registrar or to the court for the revocation of the registration of a trade mark as a defensive trade mark on any of the following grounds—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the trade mark is not otherwise registered in the name of the owner of the registered defensive trade mark; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the extent to which the registered trade mark is being or has been used does not accord with the circumstances described in subsection (1),

subsection.continued: and such revocation may be in respect of all or any of the goods or services in respect of which the registered trade mark is registered as a defensive trade mark.

subsection.content: Section 38(3) (application for registration), section 52(2)(a), (b) and (c) (revocation of registration) and such other provisions of this Ordinance as may be inconsistent with this section shall not apply in relation to defensive trade marks.
A collective mark is a sign distinguishing the goods or services of members of the association which is the owner of the sign from those of other undertakings.
This Ordinance applies to collective marks in the manner and to the extent specified in Schedule 3.

A certification mark is a sign indicating that the goods or services in connection with which it is used are certified by the owner of the sign in respect of origin, material, mode of manufacture of goods or performance of services, quality, accuracy or other characteristics.
This Ordinance applies to certification marks in the manner and to the extent specified in Schedule 4.

part.name: P9
part.heading: Paris Convention and World Trade Organization Agreement: Supplementary Provisions

section.name: s63
section.heading: Well-known trade marks: Article 6bis of Paris Convention

subsection.content: Subject to section 59 (effect of acquiescence), the owner of a trade mark which is entitled to protection under the Paris Convention as a well-known trade mark is entitled to restrain by injunction the use in Hong Kong of a trade mark which, or the essential part of which, is identical or similar to his trade mark, in relation to identical or similar goods or services, where such use is likely to cause confusion on the part of the public.
Nothing in subsection (1) affects the continuation of any use in good faith of a trade mark which was begun before the commencement* of this section.

section.name: s64
section.heading: National emblems, etc.: Article 6ter of Paris Convention

subsection.content: Subject to section 11(6) (absolute grounds for refusal of registration), a trade mark which consists of or contains the flag of a Paris Convention country or WTO member shall not be registered without the authorization of the competent authorities of that country or member, unless it appears to the Registrar that use of the flag in the manner proposed is permitted without such authorization.

Subject to section 11(6) (absolute grounds for refusal of registration), a trade mark which consists of or contains the armorial bearings or any other state emblem of a Paris Convention country or WTO member which is protected under the Paris Convention (including any armorial bearings or state emblems entitled to such protection by virtue of the World Trade Organization Agreement) shall not be registered without the authorization of the competent authorities of that country or member.

A trade mark which consists of or contains an official sign or hallmark adopted by a Paris Convention country or WTO member and indicating control and warranty shall not, where the sign or hallmark is protected under the Paris Convention (including any sign or hallmark entitled to such protection by virtue of the World Trade Organization Agreement), be registered in relation to goods or services which are the same as, or are of a similar kind to, those in relation to which it indicates control and warranty, without the authorization of the competent authorities of that country or member.

The provisions of this section as to national flags and other state emblems, and official signs or hallmarks, apply equally to anything which from a heraldic point of view imitates any such flag or other emblem, or sign or hallmark.

Nothing in this section prevents the registration of a trade mark on the application of a national of a country who is authorized to make use of a state emblem, or official sign or hallmark, of that country, notwithstanding that it is similar to that of another country.

Where by virtue of this section the authorization of the competent authorities of a Paris Convention country or WTO member is or would be required for the registration of a trade mark, those authorities are entitled to restrain by injunction any use of the trade mark in Hong Kong without their authorization.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Emblems, etc., of certain international organizations: Article 6ter of Paris Convention

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the armorial bearings, flags or other emblems; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the abbreviations and names,

subsection.continued: of international intergovernmental organizations of which one or more Paris Convention countries or WTO members are members.

subsection.leadIn: A trade mark which consists of or contains any such emblem, abbreviation or name which is protected under the Paris Convention (including any emblem, abbreviation or name entitled to such protection by virtue of the World Trade Organization Agreement) shall not be registered without the authorization of the international intergovernmental organization concerned, unless it appears to the Registrar that the use of the emblem, abbreviation or name in the manner proposed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not such as to suggest to the public that a connection exists between the organization and the trade mark; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not likely to mislead the public as to the existence of a connection between the user and the organization.

subsection.content: The provisions of this section as to emblems of an international intergovernmental organization apply equally to anything which from a heraldic point of view imitates any such emblem.

Where by virtue of this section the authorization of an international intergovernmental organization is or would be required for the registration of a trade mark, that organization is entitled to restrain by injunction any use of the trade mark in Hong Kong without its authorization.

Nothing in this section affects the rights of a person whose use in good faith of the trade mark in question began before 16 November 1977 (when the relevant provisions of the Paris Convention entered into force in relation to Hong Kong).

section.name: s66
section.heading: Notification under Article 6ter of Paris Convention

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 64 (national emblems, etc.), state emblems of a country (other than the national flag), and official signs or hallmarks, shall be regarded as protected under the Paris Convention, or as protected under the Paris Convention by virtue of the World Trade Organization Agreement, only if, or to the extent that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the country in question has notified the World Intellectual Property Organization in accordance with Article 6ter(3) of the Paris Convention that it desires to protect that emblem, sign or hallmark;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the notification remains in force; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no objection to the notification has been transmitted to the World Intellectual Property Organization on behalf of Hong Kong in accordance with Article 6ter(4) of the Paris Convention or any such objection has been withdrawn.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 65 (emblems, etc., of certain international organizations), the emblems, abbreviations and names of an international intergovernmental organization shall be regarded as protected under the Paris Convention, or as protected under the Paris Convention by virtue of the World Trade Organization Agreement, only if, or to the extent that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the organization in question has notified the World Intellectual Property Organization in accordance with Article 6ter(3) of the Paris Convention that it desires to protect that emblem, abbreviation or name;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the notification remains in force; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no objection to the notification has been transmitted to the World Intellectual Property Organization on behalf of Hong Kong in accordance with Article 6ter(4) of the Paris Convention or any such objection has been withdrawn.

subsection.content: Notification in accordance with Article 6ter(3) of the Paris Convention shall have effect only in relation to applications for registration made more than 2 months after the receipt of the notification.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar shall keep and make available for public inspection at the Registry by any person, during the normal business hours of the Registry, and free of charge, a list of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the state emblems and official signs or hallmarks; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the emblems, abbreviations and names of international intergovernmental organizations,

subsection.continued: which are for the time being protected under the Paris Convention by virtue of a notification under Article 6ter(3) of the Paris Convention.

part.name: P10
part.heading: Administrative and Other Supplementary Provisions

subsection.content: The Registrar shall keep at the Registry a register to be known as the register of trade marks.

subsection.leadIn: There shall be entered in the register in accordance with this Ordinance and the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: particulars as to applications for registration of trade marks, including the filing dates and dates of priority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the names of owners of registered trade marks;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: particulars as to transactions, instruments or events affecting rights in or under registered trade marks and applications for registration; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: such other matters as the Registrar may think fit.

subsection.content: The register need not be kept in documentary form.
Subject to any rules, the public shall have a right to inspect the register during the normal business hours of the Registry.
In relation to any portion of the register kept otherwise than in documentary form, the right of inspection conferred by subsection (1) is a right to inspect the material on the register.

Any person who applies for a certified copy of an entry in the register or a certified extract from the register shall be entitled to obtain such a copy or extract on payment of a fee prescribed in relation to certified copies and extracts.
Any person who applies for an uncertified copy or extract shall be entitled to such a copy or extract on payment of a fee prescribed in relation to uncertified copies and extracts.
Applications under this section shall be made in such manner as may be prescribed.

In relation to any portion of the register kept otherwise than in documentary form, the right to a copy or extract conferred by subsection (1) or (2) is a right to a copy or extract in a form in which it can be taken away and in which it is visible and legible.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Decisions of Registrar to be taken after hearing

subsection.content: Without prejudice to any rule of law or to any provision of this Ordinance requiring the Registrar to hear any party to proceedings before him, or to give any such party an opportunity to be heard, the Registrar shall, before taking any decision on any matter under this Ordinance or the rules which is or may be adverse to any party to any proceedings before him, give that party an opportunity to be heard.
The Registrar shall give a party to proceedings before him at least 14 days’ notice of the time when he may be heard unless that party consents to shorter notice.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Registrar’s powers in proceedings before the Registrar

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may, for the purposes of proceedings before him under this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: summon witnesses;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: receive written or oral evidence on oath or affirmation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: require the production of documents or articles for inspection and provide for the manner of inspection.

subsection.content: The Registrar may make such orders as he thinks fit as respects any matter mentioned in subsection (1).
Any order made by the Registrar under this section shall, with leave of the court, be enforceable in like manner as an order of the court.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Power to give preliminary advice etc.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may give advice on the following matters to a person who proposes to apply for the registration of a trade mark—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: whether the trade mark is likely to be refused registration on a ground mentioned in section 12(1), (2) or (3) because of an existing trade mark.

subsection.content: A person who wishes to obtain advice on a matter mentioned in subsection (1) must file a request with the Registrar in the prescribed manner.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar must give advice to the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on receipt of the request; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on payment of the applicable prescribed fee.

subsection.content: If there is a ground for refusing registration in respect of only some of the goods or services covered by the request, the advice does not have to specify the goods or services to which the ground applies.

subsection.leadIn: An applicant for the registration of a trade mark is entitled to a refund of the fees paid for filing the application if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the applicant makes the application within 3 months after the advice is given;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Registrar, after further investigation or consideration, gives notice to the applicant, stating the Registrar’s objection to the registration of the trade mark on any specified ground; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the applicant withdraws the application within the prescribed period.

subsection.leadIn: However, the applicant is not entitled to a refund if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a change occurs after the search date in the particulars entered in the register; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the change results in the Registrar’s objection mentioned in subsection (5)(c).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: existing trade mark (現有商標) means a trade mark that has already been entered in the register as at the search date;
search date (查冊日期) means the date of the search of the register by the Registrar for giving advice under this section;

specified ground (指明理由)—(a)in relation to advice that a trade mark is unlikely to be refused registration on a ground mentioned in section 11, means that a ground for refusing registration mentioned in that section applies to the trade mark; or(b)in relation to advice that a trade mark is unlikely to be refused registration on a ground mentioned in section 12(1), (2) or (3), means that a ground for refusing registration mentioned in those provisions (whichever is applicable in a particular case) applies to the trade mark.

subsection.content: In this section (except in the definition of existing trade mark in subsection (7)), a reference to a trade mark does not include a certification mark or a collective mark.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Power to specify official journal, etc.

subsection.content: The Registrar may from time to time, by notice published in the Gazette, specify a publication to be the official journal of record for the purposes of this Ordinance, with effect as of the date specified in the notice.

Where a publication is specified under subsection (1), every notice, request, document or other matter required by this Ordinance or the rules to be published in the official journal shall, from the effective date specified in the notice, be published in the publication so specified, and any reference in this Ordinance or the rules to the official journal shall be construed accordingly.
The Registrar may publish or cause to be published a journal in which there may be published such documents and information relating to trade marks as the Registrar thinks fit.
For the avoidance of doubt, the Registrar may specify the Gazette or the journal referred to in subsection (3) to be the official journal of record.
A publication specified under subsection (1) and the journal referred to in subsection (3) need not be in a documentary form.
A notice published under subsection (1) shall not be regarded as subsidiary legislation for the purpose of section 34 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1).

section.name: s74
section.heading: Power to require use of forms

subsection.content: The Registrar may require the use of such forms as he may, by notice published in the official journal, specify in connection with the registration of a trade mark or any other proceeding before him under this Ordinance.
A notice under subsection (1) may contain any direction of the Registrar with respect to the use of a form specified in the notice.
A notice published under subsection (1) shall not be regarded as subsidiary legislation for the purpose of section 34 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1).

section.name: s75
section.heading: Immunity of Registrar as regards official acts
section.leadIn: Neither the Registrar nor any public officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall be taken to warrant the validity of the registration of a trade mark under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall incur any liability by reason of, or in connection with, any examination required or authorized by this Ordinance, or any report or other proceeding consequent on any such examination.

part.crossHeading: Legal proceedings, appeals and related matters

subsection.content: Except as otherwise provided in the rules, and notwithstanding section 5 of the Official Languages Ordinance (Cap. 5), the official language in which an application for registration of a trade mark is filed shall be used as the language of the proceedings in all proceedings before the Registrar under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The rules may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require, in respect of any document filed or to be filed with the Registrar in proceedings under this Ordinance, the filing of a translation of the document into the language of the proceedings or into one or both official languages;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for the use by any person in oral proceedings before the Registrar, of a language other than the language of the proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in respect of documents to be used for the purpose of evidence in proceedings before the Registrar and which are in a language other than the language of the proceedings, provide for the filing of the document in that other language and the filing of a translation of the document into the language of the proceedings or into one of the official languages;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in respect of information provided or to be provided to the Registrar and which is to be entered in the register, require the provision of that information in both official languages; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: provide for the issue of and specify the power of the Registrar to issue documents in one or both official languages.

subsection.leadIn: Rules made for the purposes of subsection (2)(a) or (d)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may specify periods within which translations of documents into the language of the proceedings or into the official languages are to be filed or within which information in the official languages is to be provided; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may provide for extensions, upon application by a party to the proceedings, of such periods, and may require that applications for such extension shall be subject to the payment of a prescribed fee.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Procedure in case of option to apply to court or Registrar

subsection.leadIn: Where under this Ordinance a person has an option to make an application either to the court or to the Registrar on a question concerning a registered trade mark or an application for registration of a trade mark, then—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if any proceedings concerning the registered trade mark or application for registration in question is pending before the court, the application must be made to the court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if in any other case the application is made to the Registrar, he may, at any stage of the proceedings, refer the application to the court, or he may, after hearing the parties, determine the question.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) is without prejudice to the court’s powers, apart from this section, to determine any question referred to in that subsection.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Application of rules of evidence
section.content: Except as otherwise provided in this Ordinance, the Registrar is not bound by the rules of evidence in any proceedings before him under this Ordinance and may inform himself of any matter that is before him in any way that he reasonably believes to be appropriate.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4), the register shall be prima facie evidence of anything required or authorized by this Ordinance or the rules to be registered.

A certificate purporting to be signed by the Registrar and certifying that any entry in the register which he is authorized by this Ordinance or the rules to make has or has not been made, or that any other thing which he is so authorized to do has or has not been done, shall be prima facie evidence of the matters so certified.

subsection.leadIn: Each of the following, that is to say—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of an entry in the register or an extract from the register which is supplied under section 69(1) (right to copies of entries);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a copy of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any document kept in the Registry;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an extract from any such document; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: any application for registration of a trade mark,

subsection.continued: which purports to be a certified copy or a certified extract shall, subject to subsection (4), be admitted in evidence in all courts, and in all proceedings, without further proof and without production of any original.

subsection.content: This section is without prejudice to section 22A or 22B or Part IV of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) and any provision made by virtue of that section or Part.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Registration is prima facie evidence of validity, etc.
section.content: In any proceedings relating to a registered trade mark, including proceedings for rectification of the register, the registration of a person as owner of a trade mark shall be prima facie evidence of the validity of the original registration and of any subsequent assignment or other transmission of it.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Certificate of validity of contested registration

subsection.content: If in proceedings before the court the validity of the registration of a trade mark is contested and it is found by the court that the trade mark is validly registered, the court may give a certificate to that effect.

subsection.leadIn: If the court gives such a certificate and in any subsequent proceedings, either before the court or the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the validity of the registration is again questioned on the same or substantially the same grounds; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the owner of the registered trade mark obtains a final order, judgment or decision in his favour,

subsection.continued: the owner is entitled to his costs on an indemnity basis unless the court or the Registrar, as the case may be, directs otherwise.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) does not extend to the costs of an appeal in any such proceedings.

section.name: s82
section.heading: Burden in civil proceedings of proving use of trade mark

subsection.content: If, in any civil proceedings under this Ordinance in which the owner of a registered trade mark is a party, a question arises as to the use to which the trade mark has been put, the burden of proving that use shall lie with the owner.

subsection.leadIn: If, in any civil proceedings under this Ordinance in which a licensee of a registered trade mark is a party, a question arises as to the use to which the trade mark has been put, the burden of proving that use shall lie with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner of the trade mark, where he is a party to the proceedings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the licensee, where the owner is not a party to the proceedings.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Registrar’s appearance in proceedings involving the register

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings before the court involving an application for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the revocation or variation of the registration of a trade mark;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a declaration of the invalidity of the registration of a trade mark; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the rectification of the register,

subsection.continued: the Registrar is entitled to appear and be heard, and shall appear if so directed by the court.

subsection.leadIn: Unless otherwise directed by the court, the Registrar may instead of appearing, submit to the court a statement in writing signed by him, giving particulars of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings before him in relation to the matter in issue;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds of any decision given by him;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the practice of the Registrar or the Registry in like cases, if any; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: such matters relevant to the issues involved in the proceedings and within his knowledge as the Registrar thinks fit,

subsection.continued: and the statement shall be deemed to form part of the evidence in the proceedings before the court.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Appeals from decisions or orders of Registrar

subsection.content: An appeal lies to the court from any decision or order of the Registrar under this Ordinance.
Unless the court otherwise directs, any appeal under this Ordinance which concerns an application for registration of a trade mark shall be heard in public.

subsection.leadIn: In any appeal under this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Registrar shall be entitled to appear and be represented and be heard in support of his decision or order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Registrar shall appear if so directed by the court.

subsection.def: In this section, decision (決定) includes any act of the Registrar made in the exercise of a discretion vested in him by or under this Ordinance.

section.name: s85
section.heading: General powers of court
section.content: The court may, for the purpose of determining any question in the exercise of its original or appellate jurisdiction under this Ordinance, make any order or exercise any other power which the Registrar could have made or exercised for the purpose of determining that question.

subsection.content: In all proceedings before the court under this Ordinance the court may award to any party such costs as it may consider reasonable.

If in any such proceedings the court directs that any costs of one party shall be paid by another party, the court may settle the amount of the costs by fixing a lump sum or may direct that the costs shall be taxed on a scale specified by the court, being a scale of costs prescribed by rules of court.
The Registrar may, in proceedings before him under this Ordinance, by order award to any party such costs as he may consider reasonable and direct how and by what parties they are to be paid.
Any costs awarded under this section shall, if the court so orders, be recoverable by execution issued from the court as if they were payable under an order of that court.

subsection.leadIn: Provision may be made by the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to empower the Registrar, in such cases as may be prescribed, to require a party to any proceedings before him to give security for costs in relation to those proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as to the consequences if security is not given.

subsection.content: Except as otherwise provided by the rules, any act required or authorized by this Ordinance to be done by or to a person in connection with the registration of a trade mark, or any procedure relating to a trade mark, may be done by or to an agent authorized by that person orally or in writing.
The rules may in particular authorize the Registrar to refuse to recognize as an agent in respect of any business under this Ordinance any person specified for the purpose in the rules.
The Registrar shall refuse to recognize as an agent a person having neither residence nor a place of business in Hong Kong.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Hours of business and business days

subsection.content: The Registrar may give directions specifying the hours of business of the Registry for the purpose of the transaction of business under this Ordinance and the days which are business days for that purpose.

Business done on any day after the specified hours of business, or on a day which is not a business day, shall be deemed to have been done on the next business day; and where the time for doing anything under this Ordinance expires on a day which is not a business day, that time shall be extended to the next business day.
Directions given by the Registrar under this section may make different provision for different classes of business and shall be published in the prescribed manner.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Government’s right to sell forfeited articles
section.content: Nothing in this Ordinance affects the right of the Government or any person deriving title directly or indirectly from the Government to dispose of or use articles forfeited under the law relating to customs or excise.

part.name: P10A
part.heading: International Registration of Trade Marks under Madrid Protocol

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: basic application (基礎申請) means an application filed under section 38 and on the basis of which an international application is made;
basic registration (基礎註冊) means a registration under section 47 and on the basis of which an international application is made;
international application (國際申請) means an application made to the International Bureau through the Registry for registration of a trade mark in the International Register.

subsection.content: In this Part, a reference to an application filed under section 38 in the definition of basic application in subsection (1) includes a reference to an application for registration of a mark dealt with under section 10(1) of Schedule 5.
The Registrar may make rules to give effect in Hong Kong to the provisions of the Madrid Protocol.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), rules made under this Part may provide for the application of any provision in this Ordinance to the extent and in the way specified in the rules in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an international application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an international designation (HK); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a protected international trade mark (HK).

subsection.content: Sections 90C, 90D and 90E do not limit the Registrar’s powers under subsection (1).

section.name: s90C
section.heading: Rules for international application
section.leadIn: The Registrar may make rules to provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: matters relating to an international application (including the procedure for making or dealing with the application);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the procedure to be followed when—

subparagraph.content: a basic application fails, or is divided or merged; and
a basic registration ceases to be in force, or is merged; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the communication of information to the International Bureau.

section.name: s90D
section.heading: Rules for international designation (HK) and protected international trade mark (HK)

subsection.content: The Registrar may make rules to provide for matters relating to an international designation (HK) and a protected international trade mark (HK).

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the rules may provide for the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the procedure for dealing with an international designation (HK), including—

subparagraph.content: the examination of the designation by the Registrar;
the publication of the particulars of the designation in the official journal;
the conduct of proceedings for opposing the conferring of protection on the designation; and
the amendment, division or merger of the designation;

paragraph.name: b
c
d
e
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which the protection ceases and the procedure to be followed in cases of cessation;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the keeping of a register that contains matters relating to international designations (HK) and protected international trade marks (HK);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the correction, amendment or removal of any information in the register;

paragraph.name: h
j
paragraph.content: any matter incidental to or necessary to give effect to a matter mentioned in this section.

section.name: s90E
section.heading: Rules for other matters
section.leadIn: The Registrar may make rules to provide for—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the requirements in respect of the documents or other information to be filed with, or served on, the Registrar;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the rectification by the Registrar of irregularities in the procedure;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the Registrar’s power to—

subparagraph.content: extend any time limit prescribed by the rules;
order security for costs; and
tax costs;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the inspection of a document and the supply of copies of a document;

paragraph.name: f
g
paragraph.content: the record keeping and disposal arrangements of the Registry.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: prescribing anything authorized or required by a provision of this Ordinance to be prescribed; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: generally for regulating the practice and procedure under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (1), rules made under this section may make provision—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as to the manner of filing of applications for registration of a trade mark and other documents with the Registrar;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: requiring and regulating the translation of documents and the filing and authentication of any translation;

paragraph.name: d
e
f
g
paragraph.content: as to the service of documents;

paragraph.name: h
i
paragraph.content: requiring fees to be paid in connection with any such proceedings or matter or in connection with the provision of any service by the Registry;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: empowering the Registrar to tax costs awarded by him in any proceedings before him;

paragraph.name: k
l
paragraph.content: regulating the inspection of documents or articles;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: prescribing time limits for doing anything required to be done in connection with any proceedings under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: providing for the extension of any time limit so prescribed, or specified by the Registrar, whether or not it has already expired;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: as to the public inspection of the register and the supply of certified or uncertified copies of entries in, or certified or uncertified copies of extracts from, the register in the event the register is not kept in documentary form; and

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: providing for the publication and sale of documents and information by the Registry.

subsection.content: Rules made under this section may make different provisions for different cases.

subsection.leadIn: Rules made under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: authorizing the rectification of irregularities of procedure; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing for the alteration of any period of time,

subsection.continued: may authorize the extension or further extension of any period of time notwithstanding that the period has already expired.

subsection.content: Rules made under this section prescribing fees shall not be made except with the consent of the Financial Secretary.

subsection.leadIn: Any rules made under subsection (2)(i) may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe fees fixed at; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for fees to be fixed at,

subsection.continued: levels that provide for the recovery of expenditure incurred or likely to be incurred by the Government or other authority in the exercise of any or all functions under this Ordinance, and shall not be limited by reference to the amount of administrative or other costs incurred or likely to be incurred in the exercise of any particular function.

subsection.leadIn: Provision may in particular be made by the rules as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the payment of a single fee in respect of 2 or more matters; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the circumstances, if any, in which a fee may be waived or refunded.

subsection.content: Rules may be made under this section providing for arrangements to be made by the Registrar for the publication of reports of decisions or orders made by the Registrar under this Ordinance or decisions or orders relating to trade marks made by any court or body (whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere).

section.name: s92
section.heading: Regulations
section.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may by regulation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: add to Schedule 1 (Paris Convention countries and WTO members) the name of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any country which has acceded to the Paris Convention;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any country, territory or area which has acceded to the World Trade Organization Agreement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: delete from Schedule 1 the name of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any country which has denounced the Paris Convention;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any country, territory or area which has denounced the World Trade Organization Agreement;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: otherwise amend Schedule 1;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: amend Schedule 2 (determination of well-known trade marks);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: amend Schedule 3 (collective marks); and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: amend Schedule 4 (certification marks).

subsection.content: Any person who makes or causes to be made a false entry in the register, knowing or having reason to believe that it is false, commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes or causes to be made anything falsely purporting to be a copy of an entry in the register; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: produces or tenders or causes to be produced or tendered in evidence any such thing,

subsection.continued: knowing or having reason to believe that it is false, commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s94
section.heading: Falsely representing trade mark as registered

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: falsely represents that a sign is a registered trade mark; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes a false representation as to the goods or services for which a trade mark is registered,

subsection.continued: knowing or having reason to believe that the representation is false, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section, the use in Hong Kong in relation to a trade mark of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the word “registered” or “註冊”; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other word or symbol importing a reference, either express or implied, to registration,

subsection.continued: is deemed to be a representation as to registration under this Ordinance unless it is shown that the reference is to registration elsewhere than in Hong Kong and that the trade mark is in fact so registered for the goods or services in question.

section.name: s95
section.heading: Misuse of title “Trade Marks Registry”
section.content: Any person who uses on his place of business, or on any document issued by him, or otherwise, the words “Trade Marks Registry” or “商標註冊處” or any other words suggesting that his place of business is, or is officially connected with, the Registry, commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s96
section.heading: Offences committed by and proceedings relating to corporations

subsection.content: Where an offence under this Ordinance committed by a corporation is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of a director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the corporation, or a person purporting to act in any such capacity, he as well as the corporation is guilty of the offence and liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions apply for the purposes of proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance alleged to have been committed by a corporation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any rules of court relating to the service of documents; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 19A (plea by a corporation before a magistrate) and section 87 (procedure on charge of indictable offence against corporation) of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227).

def.name: Director
def.leadIn: In this section, director (董事) includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any person who occupies the position of director, by whatever name called; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person in accordance with whose directions or instructions the directors of a corporation are accustomed to act.

subsection.content: A person shall not be treated as a director of a corporation by reason only that the directors of the corporation act on advice given by him in a professional capacity.

section.name: s96A
section.heading: Interpretation of Part XIIA
section.def: document (文件) includes information recorded in any form;

enforcement officer (執法人員) means—(a)a member of the Customs and Excise Service established by section 3 of the Customs and Excise Service Ordinance (Cap. 342); or(b)an officer appointed under section 96B(1);
forfeitable item (可予沒收物件) means anything in respect of which an offence under this Ordinance has been committed;
forfeiture application (沒收申請) means an application to the court for an order set out in section 96G(3);
proceeds application (收益申請) means an application to the court for an order set out in section 96H(6);
sale application (售賣申請), in relation to a forfeitable item, means an application to the court for an order set out in section 96H(4);
specified evidence (指明證據) means anything that is or that contains, or that is likely to be, or to contain, evidence of an offence under this Ordinance;
specified recipient (指明收受者), in relation to a forfeitable item, means a person who appears to the Commissioner to be the owner of the item, one of its owners or an owner’s authorized agent.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may appoint in writing a public officer as an enforcement officer for the purposes of this Ordinance.
When exercising a power under this Part, an enforcement officer must produce evidence of the officer’s identity.

subsection.leadIn: If an enforcement officer reasonably suspects an offence under this Ordinance has been or is being committed, the officer may do all or any of the following things for the purposes of conducting an investigation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to section 96D, enter and search any place;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: make any inquiry that the officer reasonably requires for the investigation;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: inspect, examine, search, seize, remove or detain anything that appears to the officer to be specified evidence;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: require a specified person to give the officer all other assistance that the officer reasonably requires for the investigation.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified person (指明人士), in relation to an offence that an enforcement officer reasonably suspects has been or is being committed, means—(a)a person who has or may have possession or control of any information, document or any other thing relevant to the investigation of the offence; or(b)a person who may otherwise be able to assist the officer in relation to the investigation of the offence.

section.name: s96D
section.heading: Warrant to enter and search etc.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (5), an enforcement officer may only enter and search any place under the authority of a warrant issued under subsection (2).

A magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing an enforcement officer to enter and search any place if the magistrate is satisfied by information on oath that there is reasonable ground for suspecting that any specified evidence is in the place.
If a warrant has been issued under subsection (2), an enforcement officer must produce the warrant when exercising a power under this section.

subsection.leadIn: A warrant issued under subsection (2) authorizes the enforcement officer to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: forcibly enter and search the place;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: inspect, examine, search, seize, remove and detain anything in the place that appears to the officer to be specified evidence; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: detain any person found in the place until the place has been searched.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may authorize an enforcement officer to exercise the power under subsection (1) without a warrant if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is reasonable ground for suspecting that any specified evidence is in the place; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.content: the delay necessary to obtain a warrant is likely to result in the loss or destruction of evidence; or
for any other reason it would not be reasonably practicable to obtain a warrant.

subsection.content: If an enforcement officer reasonably suspects that a person has committed an offence under this Ordinance, the officer may stop, search, arrest and detain the person without a warrant.
If any person resists or attempts to evade the search, arrest or detention, an enforcement officer may use any force that is reasonably necessary to effect the search, arrest or detention.

subsection.leadIn: An enforcement officer who arrests a person may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: search the person and the vicinity of the arrest for anything that the officer reasonably suspects is of value (whether by itself or together with anything else) to the investigation of the offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: search and take possession of the thing.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in purported compliance with a requirement under section 96C(1)(e), provides any information or document that is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the information or document is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: fails to comply with a requirement under section 96C(1)(e) or (f).

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (2)(b) if the person establishes that at the time of the alleged offence, the person had a reasonable excuse for failing to provide the information or document, or to give the assistance (as the case may be).

subsection.leadIn: A person charged with an offence under this Part is taken to have established a matter that needs to be established for a defence under this Part if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue with respect to that matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s96G
section.heading: General provision on disposal of things

subsection.content: The Commissioner may, subject to any conditions the Commissioner considers appropriate and specifies in writing, release a forfeitable item or any other thing seized, removed or detained under this Part to a specified recipient.
Alternatively, the Commissioner may make a forfeiture application in relation to a forfeitable item.

subsection.leadIn: On hearing a forfeiture application and being satisfied of compliance with section 96I(1), the court may order that the forfeitable item—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be forfeited to the Government;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be destroyed; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: subject to any condition that the court specifies in the order—

subparagraph.content: be released to its owner, one of its owners or an owner’s authorized agent; or
be dealt with in any other way.

subsection.content: A forfeitable item is liable to forfeiture, destruction or other disposal, whether or not any person has been charged for the offence concerned.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 96G, this section applies if the Commissioner is of the opinion that a forfeitable item is, by its nature—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: perishable;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: difficult to store; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: likely to deteriorate before the conclusion of any proceedings relating to it.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may release the forfeitable item to a specified recipient if the recipient pays the Commissioner by way of security an amount not less than the value of the item as assessed by the Commissioner or an enforcement officer.

subsection.leadIn: Alternatively, the Commissioner may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the Commissioner considers the forfeitable item is perishable, order that it—

subparagraph.content: be sold and the sale proceeds be retained by the Commissioner; or
be destroyed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Commissioner considers the forfeitable item is difficult to store or likely to deteriorate before the conclusion of any proceedings relating to it—make a sale application.

subsection.content: On hearing a sale application and being satisfied of compliance with section 96I(1), the court may order that the forfeitable item be sold and the sale proceeds be retained by the Commissioner.
Also, the Commissioner may make a proceeds application.

subsection.leadIn: On hearing a proceeds application, the court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: order the payment made to the Commissioner under subsection (2) to be—

subparagraph.content: forfeited to the Government; or
paid to the person giving the security or the person entitled to claim the payment or the forfeitable item; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: order the sale proceeds retained by the Commissioner under subsection (3)(a)(i) or by order under subsection (4) to be—

subparagraph.content: forfeited to the Government; or
paid to the person entitled to claim the proceeds or the forfeitable item.

section.name: s96I
section.heading: Notification requirement for certain intended applications

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner must notify the owner of a forfeitable item or the owner’s authorized agent that the Commissioner intends to make a forfeiture application or sale application if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the application is to be made otherwise than in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the owner of the item can be found.

subsection.content: If there is more than one owner of the forfeitable item, it is sufficient to give notice to one of the owners or an owner’s authorized agent.

section.name: s96J
section.heading: International co-operation
section.leadIn: The Commissioner may, for the purpose of promoting international co-operation in the protection of intellectual property rights, disclose any information obtained under this Part to any authority that is responsible for the enforcement of those rights in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Paris Convention country;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a WTO member; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other country, territory or area as the Commissioner considers appropriate.

section.name: s96K
section.heading: Delegation
section.content: The Commissioner may, in writing, delegate to a public officer any of his or her functions or powers under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: Neither the Commissioner nor an enforcement officer is civilly liable for an act done or omitted to be done by him or her in good faith in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: performing or purportedly performing a function conferred on him or her by this Part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exercising or purportedly exercising a power conferred on him or her by this Part.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not affect any liability of the Government for the act or omission.

part.name: P13
part.heading: Transitional Provisions, Consequential and Related Amendments and Repeals

subsection.content: Schedule 5 (transitional matters) has effect as respects transitional matters.
The Chief Executive in Council may make regulations containing provisions of a savings or transitional nature consequent on the enactment of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (2), the regulations may in particular provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the application of provisions of this Ordinance or the rules made under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the continued application of provisions of the repealed Trade Marks Ordinance (Cap. 43) or the repealed Trade Marks Rules (Cap. 43 sub. leg. A), (Amended E.R. 7 of 2020)

subsection.continued: in connection with any matter specified in the regulations.

subsection.content: Regulations made under this section may, if they so provide, be deemed to have come into operation on a date earlier than the date on which they are published in the Gazette but not earlier than the date on which Schedule 5 (transitional matters) comes into operation.

subsection.leadIn: To the extent that any regulations come into operation on a date earlier than the date on which they are published in the Gazette, those regulations shall be construed so as not to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affect, in a manner prejudicial to any person, the rights of that person existing before the date on which the regulations are published in the Gazette; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: impose liabilities on any person in respect of anything done, or omitted to be done, before that date.

subsection.content: In the event of an inconsistency between any regulations made under this section and the provisions of Schedule 5, the latter shall prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
