subsection.content: In determining for the purposes of section 4 (meaning of well-known trade mark) whether a trade mark is well known in Hong Kong, the Registrar or the court shall take into account any factors from which it may be inferred that the trade mark is well known in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: In particular, the Registrar or the court shall consider any information submitted to the Registrar or the court from which it may be inferred that the trade mark is, or is not, well known in Hong Kong, including, but not limited to, information concerning the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the degree of knowledge or recognition of the trade mark in the relevant sectors of the public;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the duration, extent and geographical area of any use of the trade mark;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the duration, extent and geographical area of any promotion of the trade mark, including advertising or publicity and the presentation, at fairs or exhibitions, of the goods or services to which the trade mark applies;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: the record of successful enforcement of rights in the trade mark, in particular, the extent to which the trade mark has been recognized as a well-known trade mark by competent authorities in non-Hong Kong jurisdictions; and (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the value associated with the trade mark.

subsection.content: The factors mentioned in subsection (2) are intended to serve as guidelines to assist the Registrar and the court to determine whether the trade mark is well known in Hong Kong. It is not a precondition for reaching that determination that information be submitted with respect to any of those factors or that equal weight be given to each of them. Rather, the determination in each case will depend upon the particular circumstances of that case. In some cases all of the factors may be relevant. In other cases some of the factors may be relevant. In still other cases none of the factors may be relevant, and the decision may be based on additional factors that are not mentioned in subsection (2). Such additional factors may be relevant alone, or in combination with one or more of the factors mentioned in subsection (2).

def.name: RelevantSectorsOfThePublic
def.leadIn: For the purpose of subsection (2)(a), relevant sectors of the public (有關的公眾界別) includes, but is not limited to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: actual or potential consumers of the type of goods or services to which the trade mark applies;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: persons involved in channels of distribution of the type of goods or services to which the trade mark applies; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: business circles dealing with the type of goods or services to which the trade mark applies.

subsection.content: Where a trade mark is determined to be well known in at least one relevant sector of the public in Hong Kong, it shall be considered to be well known in Hong Kong.

subsection.def: For the purpose of subsection (2)(e), competent authorities in non-Hong Kong jurisdictions (非香港司法管轄區的主管當局) means administrative, judicial or quasi-judicial authorities in jurisdictions other than Hong Kong that are competent to determine whether a trade mark is a well-known trade mark, or in enforcing the protection of well-known trade marks, in their respective jurisdictions. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Factors not required to be established
section.leadIn: For the purpose of determining whether a trade mark is well known in Hong Kong, it is not necessary to establish—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the trade mark has been used, or has been registered, in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that an application for registration of the trade mark has been filed in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the trade mark is well known, or has been registered, in a jurisdiction other than Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that an application for registration of the trade mark has been filed in a jurisdiction other than Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: that the trade mark is well known by the public at large in Hong Kong.

schedule.name: sch3
schedule.heading: Collective Marks

section.name: s1
section.content: This Ordinance applies to collective marks subject to the provisions of this Schedule.

schedule.crossHeading: Signs of which a collective mark may consist

section.name: s2
section.content: In relation to a collective mark, the reference in section 3(1) of this Ordinance (meaning of trade mark) to distinguishing goods or services of one undertaking from those of other undertakings shall be construed as a reference to distinguishing goods or services of members of the association which is the owner of the collective mark from those of other undertakings.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding section 11(1)(c) of this Ordinance (absolute grounds for refusal of registration), a collective mark which consists of a sign which may serve, in trade or business, to designate the geographical origin of goods or services may be registered.

However, the owner of such a collective mark is not entitled to prohibit the use of the sign in accordance with honest practices in industrial or commercial matters, in particular, by a person who is entitled to use a geographical name.

schedule.crossHeading: Mark not to be misleading as to character or significance

subsection.content: A collective mark shall not be registered if the public is liable to be misled as regards its character or significance, in particular, if it is likely to be taken to be something other than a collective mark.
The Registrar may accordingly require that a sign in respect of which an application is made for registration as a collective mark include some indication that it is a collective mark.
Notwithstanding section 46 of this Ordinance (amendment of application), an application may be amended so as to comply with any requirement imposed by the Registrar under subsection (2).

schedule.crossHeading: Regulations governing use of collective mark

subsection.content: An applicant for registration of a collective mark must file with the Registrar regulations governing the use of the collective mark.

subsection.leadIn: The regulations must specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the persons authorized to use the collective mark;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the conditions of membership of the association; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where they exist, the conditions of use of the collective mark, including any sanctions against misuse.

subsection.content: The rules may impose further requirements with which the regulations must comply.
A collective mark shall not be registered unless the regulations governing its use comply with section 5(2) of this Schedule and any further requirements imposed by the rules.
A collective mark shall not be registered if the regulations governing its use are contrary to accepted principles of morality.
An applicant for registration of a collective mark must file the regulations and pay the prescribed fee before the end of the prescribed period after the date of the application for registration.
If an applicant fails to comply with subsection (3), the application shall be deemed to be withdrawn.
The Registrar shall consider whether the requirements mentioned in section 6(1) and (2) of this Schedule are met.

If it appears to the Registrar that the requirements mentioned in section 6(1) and (2) of this Schedule are not met, he shall inform the applicant and give him an opportunity to make representations or to file amended regulations within such period as the Registrar may specify.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar shall refuse the application if the applicant fails to respond before the end of the specified period or fails before the end of that period—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: to file regulations amended so as to meet those requirements.

subsection.content: If it appears to the Registrar that the requirements mentioned in section 6(1) and (2) of this Schedule, and the other requirements for registration, are met, he shall accept the application and shall proceed in accordance with section 43 of this Ordinance (publication of particulars of application).

section.name: s8
section.content: In addition to any other grounds on which the registration may be opposed, notice of opposition may be given relating to any of the matters mentioned in section 6(1) and (2) of this Schedule.

schedule.crossHeading: Regulations to be open to inspection

section.name: s9
section.content: The regulations governing the use of a registered collective mark shall be open to public inspection in the same way as the register.

subsection.content: An amendment of the regulations governing the use of a registered collective mark is not effective until the amended regulations are filed and are accepted by the Registrar.
Before accepting any amended regulations the Registrar may, in any case where it appears to him expedient to do so, cause or require notice of the amendment to be published in the official journal.
If notice of the amendment is published in the official journal, notice of opposition may be given relating to any of the matters mentioned in section 6(1) and (2) of this Schedule.

section.name: s11
section.leadIn: The following provisions apply in relation to an authorized user of a registered collective mark as in relation to a licensee of a registered trade mark—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 18(6) of this Ordinance (infringement of registered trade mark); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 25(3) of this Ordinance (order for disposal).

subsection.content: The following provisions, which correspond to the provisions of section 35 of this Ordinance (rights of licensees generally), have effect as regards the rights of an authorized user in relation to infringement of a registered collective mark.

An authorized user is entitled, subject to any agreement to the contrary between him and the owner of the registered collective mark, to call on the owner to take infringement proceedings in respect of any matter which affects his interests.

subsection.leadIn: If the owner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuses to do so; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to do so within 1 month after being called upon to do so,

subsection.continued: the authorized user may bring the proceedings in his own name as if he were the owner.

subsection.content: Where infringement proceedings are brought by virtue of this section, the authorized user may not, without the leave of the court, proceed with the action unless the owner is either joined as a plaintiff or added as a defendant.
Nothing in subsection (4) affects the granting of interlocutory relief on an application by an authorized user alone.
A person who is added as a defendant as mentioned in subsection (4) shall not be made liable for any costs in the action unless he takes part in the proceedings.

In infringement proceedings brought by the owner of a registered collective mark, any loss suffered or likely to be suffered by authorized users shall be taken into account; and the court may give such directions as it thinks fit as to the extent to which the plaintiff is to hold the proceeds of any pecuniary remedy on behalf of such users.

section.name: s13
section.leadIn: Apart from the grounds of revocation mentioned in section 52 of this Ordinance (revocation of registration), the registration of a collective mark may be revoked on the ground—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: that the owner has failed to observe, or to secure the observance of, the regulations governing the use of the collective mark; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that an amendment of the regulations has been made so that the regulations—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: are contrary to accepted principles of morality.

section.name: s14
section.content: Apart from the grounds of invalidity mentioned in section 53 of this Ordinance (declaration of invalidity of registration), the registration of a collective mark may be declared invalid on the ground that the collective mark was registered in breach of section 4(1) or 6(1) or (2) of this Schedule.

schedule.name: sch4
schedule.heading: Certification Marks

section.name: s1
section.content: This Ordinance applies to certification marks subject to the provisions of this Schedule.

schedule.crossHeading: Signs of which a certification mark may consist

section.name: s2
section.content: In relation to a certification mark, the reference in section 3(1) of this Ordinance (meaning of trade mark) to distinguishing goods or services of one undertaking from those of other undertakings shall be construed as a reference to distinguishing goods or services which are certified from those which are not.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding section 11(1)(c) of this Ordinance (absolute grounds for refusal of registration), a certification mark which consists of a sign which may serve, in trade or business, to designate the geographical origin of goods or services may be registered.

However, the owner of such a certification mark is not entitled to prohibit the use of the sign in accordance with honest practices in industrial or commercial matters, in particular, by a person who is entitled to use a geographical name.

schedule.crossHeading: Nature of owner’s trade or business

section.name: s4
section.content: A certification mark shall not be registered if the owner carries on a trade or business involving the supply of goods or services of the kind certified.

schedule.crossHeading: Mark not to be misleading as to character or significance

subsection.content: A certification mark shall not be registered if the public is liable to be misled as regards its character or significance, in particular, if it is likely to be taken to be something other than a certification mark.
The Registrar may accordingly require that a sign in respect of which an application is made for registration as a certification mark include some indication that it is a certification mark.
Notwithstanding section 46 of this Ordinance (amendment of application), an application may be amended so as to comply with any requirement imposed by the Registrar under subsection (2).

schedule.crossHeading: Regulations governing use of certification mark

subsection.content: An applicant for registration of a certification mark must file with the Registrar regulations governing the use of the certification mark.

subsection.leadIn: The regulations must indicate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the persons authorized to use the certification mark;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the characteristics to be certified by the certification mark;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: how the certifying body is to test those characteristics and to supervise the use of the certification mark;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the fees, if any, to be paid in connection with the use of the certification mark; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the procedures for resolving disputes.

subsection.content: The rules may impose further requirements with which the regulations must comply.

subsection.leadIn: A certification mark shall not be registered unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the regulations governing its use comply with section 6(2) of this Schedule and any further requirements imposed by the rules; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant is competent to certify the goods or services for which the certification mark is to be registered.

subsection.content: A certification mark shall not be registered if the regulations governing its use are contrary to accepted principles of morality.
An applicant for registration of a certification mark must file the regulations and pay the prescribed fee before the end of the prescribed period after the date of the application for registration.
If an applicant fails to comply with subsection (3), the application shall be deemed to be withdrawn.
The Registrar shall consider whether the requirements mentioned in section 7(1) and (2) of this Schedule are met.

If it appears to the Registrar that the requirements mentioned in section 7(1) and (2) of this Schedule are not met, he shall inform the applicant and give him an opportunity to make representations or to file amended regulations within such period as the Registrar may specify.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar shall refuse the application if the applicant fails to respond before the end of the specified period or fails before the end of that period—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: to file regulations amended so as to meet those requirements.

subsection.content: If it appears to the Registrar that the requirements mentioned in section 7(1) and (2) of this Schedule, and the other requirements for registration, are met, he shall accept the application and shall proceed in accordance with section 43 of this Ordinance (publication of particulars of application).

section.name: s9
section.content: In addition to any other grounds on which the registration may be opposed, notice of opposition may be given relating to any of the matters mentioned in section 7(1) and (2) of this Schedule.

schedule.crossHeading: Regulations to be open to inspection

section.name: s10
section.content: The regulations governing the use of a registered certification mark shall be open to public inspection in the same way as the register.

subsection.content: An amendment of the regulations governing the use of a registered certification mark is not effective until the amended regulations are filed and are accepted by the Registrar.
Before accepting any amended regulations the Registrar may, in any case where it appears to him expedient to do so, cause or require notice of the amendment to be published in the official journal.
If notice of the amendment is published in the official journal, notice of opposition may be given relating to the matters mentioned in section 7(1) and (2) of this Schedule.

schedule.crossHeading: Consent to assignment of registered certification mark

section.name: s12
section.content: The assignment or other transmission of a registered certification mark is not effective without the consent of the Registrar.

section.name: s13
section.leadIn: The following provisions apply in relation to an authorized user of a registered certification mark as in relation to a licensee of a registered trade mark—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 18(6) of this Ordinance (infringement of registered trade mark); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 25(3) of this Ordinance (order for disposal).

section.name: s14
section.content: In infringement proceedings brought by the owner of a registered certification mark, any loss suffered or likely to be suffered by authorized users shall be taken into account; and the court may give such directions as it thinks fit as to the extent to which the plaintiff is to hold the proceeds of any pecuniary remedy on behalf of such users.

section.name: s15
section.leadIn: Apart from the grounds of revocation mentioned in section 52 of this Ordinance (revocation of registration), the registration of a certification mark may be revoked on the ground—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the owner has begun to carry on such a trade or business as is mentioned in section 4 of this Schedule;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: that the owner has failed to observe, or to secure the observance of, the regulations governing the use of the certification mark;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: that an amendment of the regulations has been made so that the regulations—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: are contrary to accepted principles of morality; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: that the owner is no longer competent to certify the goods or services for which the certification mark is registered.

section.name: s16
section.content: Apart from the grounds of invalidity mentioned in section 53 of this Ordinance (declaration of invalidity of registration), the registration of a certification mark may be declared invalid on the ground that the certification mark was registered in breach of section 4, 5(1) or 7(1) or (2) of this Schedule.

schedule.name: sch5

subsection.leadIn: In this Schedule—
subsection.def: commencement date* (生效日期) means the date on which this Schedule comes into operation;

existing registered mark (現有註冊標記) means a mark that, immediately before the commencement date, constituted a registered trade mark, certification trade mark or defensive trade mark under the repealed Ordinance;

paragraph.name: a

paragraph.name: b
